clean_story:
"Glowing pictures. Electron beams draw them. "

The name cathode ray tube describes how it works: a cathode (negative electrode) shoots rays (beams of electrons) inside a sealed tube to light up a screen.

Most remember CRTs as the bulky TVs and monitors of the 1990s—heavy, deep, and flickery. But their real magic was speed and precision.
Inside, an electron gun fires a beam at a phosphor-coated screen, like spraying invisible ink that glows when hit.
Magnetic coils steer the beam left-right, up-down, painting images 60 times per second—fast enough to trick your eyes into seeing motion.
Before CRTs, screens were slow or static. Early radar displays in WWII used them to track planes in real time.
By the 1950s, they became the default for TVs, then computer monitors—even the first video games (Pong, 1972) relied on their crisp, responsive dots.
Their downfall? Size and energy. A 27-inch CRT weighed 60+ pounds; LCDs did the same job in a fraction of the space.
Yet CRTs had zero input lag, making them beloved by gamers and graphic designers long after flatscreens arrived.
Three related subjects are phosphor decay time, vector graphics monitors, and electron beam lithography.
